title: The Office MSD
description: How I built a Master Ship display for my office

This is my first blog post! 

## Explaining the Picture

It's Jerry

title: Introducing the Blog

body.raw:
Being a part of a tech start up is an exciting rollercoaster of a journey. While they often come with higher salaries and better perks than more established brands, they also come with their own risks.

That, in short, is how I have found myself at the receiving end of a redundancy process for the second job in a row. 

## My journey

I've always been what I would describe as a tech enthusiast and for that, I blame Star Trek. Hours upon hours of my formative years were spent in front of a TV screen watching the valiant crews of the Enterprise('s'), Voyager and Deep Space Nine solve their problems with technobabble and tapping panels.

Who wouldn't want that as a career right? Unfortunately for me, I wasn't diagnosed with ADHD until I was 29. So trying to sit down and learn how to code, or pay attention as a teenager was a definite mountain. 

Fortunately for me, I was diagnosed and now I have medication which helps me sit down and pay attention to what I'm reading, rather than get distracted by the latest shiny thing. I've also found my way into the tech industry without a computer science degree or strong set of coding skills. With thanks to Monzo for taking a chance on me the better part of a decade ago for their customer support team. 

I've also been lucky in that I've been working for CodeSandbox, who supported me with a web dev essentials course last year and with giving me work projects that helped me to retain and further evolve my coding skills. 

But as said, now I'm redundant. So it's time to think about how to market myself in the current tech world. 

This brings me to:

## This site

With the tech sector contracting in a number of areas in recent years, and lots of redundancies occuring it's not the best time for somebody in their 30s who is very much a junior to get a job. 

But that doesn't mean I can't try to improve my chances, and that's why I built this site. It's a bit of a showcase of everything that I do (and will do). It should also help keep me accountable for projects I start, because I have quite the backlog there already... 

So, please feel free to have a look around. At the time of writing there isn't much here yet. But there will be in the future...

title: Review - Master Replicas' Caretaker's Array

body.raw:
When Eaglemoss/Hero Collector went bust back in 2022, their remaining stock and upcoming products seemed lost forever. There was hope that some may turn up in bargain stores from the liquidation sale (and to be fair, some did!) but for the most part it was eBay at inflated prices, or out of luck.

Enter [Master Replicas](https://www.masterreplicas.com/) who took on the gargantuan task of locating all the stock, paying off debts and shipping tiny models from around the world to and then from the UK (where they're based). 

The Caretaker's Array in Star Trek merchandise was (is?) somewhat of a cursed item. There have been multiple attempts to get one of shelves from various companies but aside from a limited production run from Micro Machines (which ended up looking more like Atlantis, from Stargate: Atlantis) none have made it. 

Fortunately, Master Replicas' got the produced Hero Collector stock out to fans, so a decent Array is finally out in the world. 

[Read the review on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/master-replicas-caretakers-array-review/)

title: Interview - Derek Tyler Attico - Author of The Autobiography of Benjamin Sisko

body.raw:
A bit of a two-fer here. Following on from my review of the Autobiography of Benjamin Sisko, I had a chance to speak with the author himself!

[Read the interview on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/interview-derek-tyler-attico-author-of-the-autobiography-of-benjamin-sisko/)

title: Interview - Star Trek Prodigy writers Julie & Shawna Benson

body.raw:
The next in my Star Trek Prodigy Interview series, I got to speak to the Benson sisters (Julie & Shawna) who also wrote for Masters of the Universe, Wu Assassins and the 100! 

[Read the interview on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/interview-star-trek-prodigy-writers-julie-shawna-benson/)

title: Interview - Star Trek Prodigy writer Chad Quandt

body.raw:
Another perk of writing for a fan site is that you occasionally get to 'meet your heroes'. The creatives that put their blood, sweat and tears into the universes that we love as fans. Here I got to interview Chad Quandt, who has written for Trollhunters, Wizards and Teen Titans Go! As well as Star Trek. 

[Read the interview on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/interview-star-trek-prodigy-writer-chad-quandt/)

title: Article - Will Star Trek Discovery Season 5 explain the Romulan Supernova?

body.raw:
Another one of those fun speculation articles! Always fun to write. 


[Read the article on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/will-star-trek-discovery-season-5-explain-the-romulan-supernova/)

title: Review - EXO-6 Archer & Shran

body.raw:
A couple of additions here to my personal Exo-6 1:6 Trek museum. My collecting approach since the range was announced was to collect 3 main cast + 1 antagonist from each major series. 

For Enterprise, Archer as one of the main cast and Shran as the antagonist were an easy choice. 

[Read the review on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/exo-6-archer-shran-review/)

title: Review - EXO-6 Locutus

body.raw:
Another of my Exo-6 1:6 figure reviews, this time looking at the antagonist of the iconic Next Generation two parter 'The Best of Both Worlds' - Locutus of Borg. 

[Read the review on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/exo-6-locutus-review-your-resistance-is-hopeless/)

title: Review - EXO-6 Commander Saru

body.raw:
My original title was 'Here's to you, a 1:6 Saru review' which I still think was a great play on words, but didn't fit with the overall title structure the site adopted. 

I was proud of my photography for this one. 

[Read the review on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/commander-saru-review/)

title: Review - Star Trek Picard - Firewall

body.raw:
As a Voyager fan, this is a book I couldn't wait to have my hands on. It didn't disappoint! 

[Read the review on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/review-the-autobiography-of-benjamin-sisko/)

title: Article - The Measure of a Trek - Taking a look at Star Trek Discovery

body.raw:
Having been a fan of Star Trek since the 90s, I've been around the fandom circuit enough times to find the ever more popular kneejerk 'hate the new thing' mindset absolutely exhausting.

Discovery isn't a perfect show, but it gets a lot more hate than it deserves because outrage sells and the show that took on the responsibility of refining Star Trek for the first time since The Next Generation (TNG) was an easy target. 

This was my attempt to even the scales a bit, and take a look back at the show following the news of it's cancellation through the playful lens of one of TNGs most iconic episodes. 

[Read the article on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/taking-a-look-at-star-trek-discovery/)

title: Article - Has the original USS Enterprise filming model been found?

body.raw:
This was a wild story, given the timing. 

A few months earlier a bunch of iconic Star Trek props had resurfaced in the [Greg Jein auction](https://entertainment.ha.com/c/search/results.zx?dept=2182&sold_status=1526&archive_state=5327&mode=archive&auction_name=7278&auction_year=2023&ic4=GalleryView-AuctionNo-051517). Not even a month later, the original (and I mean original, this one was used in the first pilot) Enterprise model resurfaced.

In an eBay listing. The owner seemed to have absolutely no idea what they actually had. It had gone missing in the 70s! There was a happy resolution in this case, the model was returned to the Roddenberry estate, it's rightful owner. 

[Read the article on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/has-the-original-uss-enterprise-filming-model-been-found/)

title: Article - Star Trek Picard's Nemesis Connections

body.raw:
I've always felt that the 'final' (tbd at this point) Next Generation (TNG) cast film got an unfairly bad rap. Given my defence of Discovery maybe there is an element of truth in that I just like to defend things that others attack. 

To explain my defence, Nemesis certainly isn't a _great_ Star Trek Movie. It was also, objectively, a terrible send off for one of Star Trek's most iconic ensembles. Between Patrick Stewart wanting a Dune buggy scene because he liked them, Brent Spiner wanting to kill off Data because he felt he was becoming 'too old' to play an ageless android (despite a line in TNG stating that he could age) and the director being the result of a 'you scratch my back, I'll scratch yours' deal and not caring about Star Trek or the cast in the slightest - to the point of constantly calling the great Levar Burton 'Laverne' it didn't really stand a chance. 

But none the less, it has amazing CG effects that hold up even today. The battle (despite being slightly Wrath of Khan derivative) was incredible. Tom Hardy delivers a great performance without much to work with...

There's a lot to like, but the franchise has been trying to repair the damage this film did to TNG fans ever since. Most notably Star Trek: Picard. 

This article covers a number of those connections. With a focus on the third season (that was airing at the time).

[Read the article on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/star-trek-picards-nemesis-connections/)

title: Review - Star Trek Picard Season 3 Blu-ray

body.raw:
It had it's flaws, but I did like Picard season 3. The physical release is one of Trek's all time greats in terms of special features as well. 

[Read the review on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/star-trek-picard-season-3-blu-ray-review/)

title: Review - Star Trek Prodigy Season One Blu-ray

body.raw:
When Paramount unceremoniously cancelled Star Trek Prodigy last year, there was a significant outcry from fans. In no small part generated by the fact that the show had only had half a season released on physical media. 

After said outcry, they rushed a release of the complete full season which released in late September. 

[Read the review on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/star-trek-prodigy-season-one-blu-ray-review/)

title: Article - Star Trek Prodigy - The Story So Far

body.raw:
As a Star Trek: Voyager and Star Wars: The Clone Wars fan, Star Trek: Prodigy hit all the right notes for me. Naturally this meant I jumped at the chance to write content for it where I could.

[Read the article on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/star-trek-prodigy-the-story-so-far/)

title: Article - Star Trek Prodigy - Trailer Breakdown

body.raw:
A big part of content writing for fan sites is covering and 'breaking down' marketing materials for other fans. These articles tend to feed and generate discussion around the show. 

[Read the article on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/new-star-trek-prodigy-trailer-breakdown/)

title: Review - The autobiography of Benjamin Sisko

body.raw:
I've long been a fan of the Star Trek 'Autobiography of...' book series and had the fortune to review one of them last year as it came out. 

[Read the review on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/review-the-autobiography-of-benjamin-sisko/)

title: Review - Star Trek Strange New Worlds Season 2 Steelbook

body.raw:
Strange New Worlds Season 2 release was an odd one, it lacked the extra content of the previous Picard release but included a bunch of extras instead? 

The season was good anyway, love a good musical. 

[Read the review on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/review-star-trek-strange-new-worlds-season-2-steelbook/)

title: Article - Wil Wheaton joins Star Trek Online

body.raw:
This was my first article for Trek Central. 

[Read it on their website](https://trekcentral.net/wil-wheaton-joins-star-trek-online/)

title: Article - Which Star Trek Characters could appear in the Academy series?

body.raw:
Another key component of the modern content writing landscape. Rampant speculation! In fandom spaces this is always a good bit of fun. Though you often have to keep in mind that some fans may be dissapointed if your predictions don't come to pass. 

[Read the article on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/which-star-trek-characters-could-appear-in-the-academy-series/)

title: Review - Star Trek The Next Generation 4K Movie Collection

body.raw:
Another thankful freebie, as I had also purchased all of these films multiple times! Still, despite some odd artwork these are the best versions of these films video and audio wise. 

[Read the review on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/star-trek-the-next-generation-4k-movie-collection-review/)

title: Review - Star Trek 4K 6-Movie Collection

body.raw:
One of the perks of writing for a fan site is that you occasionally get a freebie to review. This boxset was my first (I paid for the Saru figure), which was fortunate because I had already paid for all the movies in it about 4 different times across the various re-releases over the years. 

[Read the review on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/star-trek-4k-6-movie-collection-boxset-review/)

title: Review - BlueBrixx USS Voyager & Delta Flyer

body.raw:
Another of my own purchases to review here. I've wanted LEGO to take on the Star Trek license for decades, but Paramount always seems to have other plans. 

Fortunately in this case, another 'building blocks' brand took it on and has gone deeper into the franchise than I think Lego would have dared, it's nice that there are a mix of pluses and minuses verses Lego quality as well. I certainly remember the 'off-brand' kits of yesteryear that didn't have any pros to weigh up against the cons! 

[Read the review on the Trek Central website](https://trekcentral.net/bluebrixx-star-trek-voyager-delta-flyer-review/)
